history.content:
I think cs 168 was the first cs upper div that I loved! It was a breath of fresh air from the lect + disc + lab + hw + proj; rinse and repeat. There were disc and projects but they directly enforced the material in the lecture. This is a class where if you don't watch/don't attend lecture you probably should steer away from. Exams are largely conceptual multiple choice tests. 

That being said, I loved it. It was a new topic that was explained to you from the start. 162 hinges on you understanding 61c and the same with many other upper divs. 168 started from scratch; the first two lectures are history lessons!

children.subject: Thank you! Have you taken 161? How much network does 161 cover?

I did. Again, only protocols (and very specific ones). TCP (surface only), DNS (this one I think better than 168, tho) and TLS (this is not covered in 168 bc it has nothing to do with networking per se, but it is rather about establishing a reliable connection).

I think 161 is a great course and very applicable, so I think it depends on what you are more interested about personally. Altho imo Security is more needed for a SWE job, but I'm sure that for the product you are working on, someone will make sure that it is secure anyway

To answer your question:

162 will not teach you anything about computer networks. It goes super briefly over TCP (not emphasized) and explain sockets and IPC at a very high level. This is not what networks are about.

To support the student answer:

I think that 168 is useful to understand networks but it really also gives a break of the usual CS course structure, as mentioned by the student answer. It is also a great course for understanding system design from the start and for understanding how to manage very complex systems

history.content: I am a senior graduating next semester and need one more CS upper div. I am going to take CS 162, and I am deciding whether to take 168 or not. For a person not going to specialize in computer network, does 162 cover enough computer network knowledge for a general software engineer?
history.subject: How useful is CS 168?
